TypeScript.definition: A strongly typed superset of JavaScript.

React.definition: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces.

Python.definition: A high-level, interpreted programming language known for its readability and versatility.

Java.definition: A widely used, class-based, object-oriented programming language designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible.

R.definition: A programming language and environment for statistical computing and graphics.

JavaScript.definition: A versatile, high-level programming language that is one of the core technologies of the web.

Hadoop.definition: An open-source framework for distributed storage and processing of large data sets using the MapReduce programming model.

HBase.definition: A distributed, scalable, big data store modeled after Google's Bigtable and written in Java.

Pig.definition: A high-level platform for creating MapReduce programs used with Hadoop.

MapReduce.definition: A programming model and processing technique for distributed computing based on Java, used by Hadoop.

Sawzall.definition: A programming language developed by Google for processing large amounts of data.

Bigtable.definition: A distributed storage system for managing structured data, designed to scale to a very large size.

Hive.definition: A data warehouse software project built on top of Hadoop for providing data query and analysis.

Spark.definition: An open-source unified analytics engine for large-scale data processing.

TensorFlow.definition: An open-source platform for machine learning developed by Google.

PyTorch.definition: An open-source machine learning library based on the Torch library, developed by Facebook's AI Research lab.

Kubernetes.definition: An open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

Terraform.definition: An open-source infrastructure as code software tool created by HashiCorp.

Linux.definition: An open-source family of Unix-like operating systems based on the Linux kernel.

Unix.definition: A family of multitasking, multiuser computer operating systems that derive from the original AT&T Unix.

PTP.definition: Precision Time Protocol, a protocol used to synchronize clocks throughout a computer network.

RTOS.definition: Real-Time Operating System, an operating system intended to serve real-time application requests.

FreeRTOS.definition: An open-source real-time operating system for embedded devices.

SafeRTOS.definition: A safety-critical real-time operating system derived from FreeRTOS, designed for use in safety-critical applications.

SOAP.definition: Simple Object Access Protocol, a messaging protocol for exchanging structured information in web services.

REST.definition: Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for designing networked applications.

XML.definition: Extensible Markup Language, a markup language that defines a set of rules for encoding documents in a format readable by both humans and machines.

JSON.definition: JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data-interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write, and easy for machines to parse and generate.

HTML.definition: HyperText Markup Language, the standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser.

GraphQL.definition: A query language for APIs and a runtime for executing those queries by using a type system you define for your data.

RPC.definition: Remote Procedure Call, a protocol that one program can use to request a service from a program located on another computer in a network.

Flutter.definition: An open-source UI software development toolkit created by Google for building natively compiled applications for mobile, web, and desktop from a single codebase.

Vercel.definition: A cloud platform for static sites and Serverless Functions that enables developers to host websites and web services that deploy instantly, scale automatically, and require no supervision.

Ruby.definition: A dynamic, open-source programming language with a focus on simplicity and productivity.

SQL.definition: Structured Query Language, a standard programming language for managing and manipulating relational databases.

Go.definition: An open-source programming language that makes it easy to build simple, reliable, and efficient software. Also known as Golang.

NodeJS.definition: An open-source, cross-platform JavaScript runtime environment that executes JavaScript code outside a web browser.

Git.definition: A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.

Docker.definition: An open-source platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers.

JWT.definition: JSON Web Token, an open standard for securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object.

Lambda.definition: AWS Lambda, a serverless compute service that runs code in response to events and automatically manages the underlying compute resources.

MVC.definition: Model-View-Controller, a software design pattern commonly used for developing user interfaces that divides an application into three interconnected components.

NPM.definition: Node Package Manager, the default package manager for the JavaScript runtime environment Node.js.

NoSQL.definition: A class of database management systems that do not use the traditional relational database model, often used for large sets of distributed data.

OAuth.definition: An open standard for access delegation commonly used for token-based authentication and authorization on the internet.

PaaS.definition: Platform as a Service, a category of cloud computing services that provides a platform allowing customers to develop, run, and manage applications.

Redux.definition: An open-source JavaScript library for managing and centralizing application state, commonly used with React.

S3.definition: Amazon Simple Storage Service, an object storage service that offers industry-leading scalability, data availability, security, and performance.

SaaS.definition: Software as a Service, a software distribution model in which applications are hosted by a service provider and made available to customers over the internet.

SSL/TLS.definition: Secure Sockets Layer and Transport Layer Security, cryptographic protocols designed to provide communications security over a computer network.

WebSocket.definition: A computer communications protocol, providing full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection, commonly used in real-time web applications.

Webpack.definition: An open-source JavaScript module bundler, primarily for JavaScript, but it can transform front-end assets like HTML, CSS, and images if the corresponding loaders are included.

YAML.definition: YAML Ain't Markup Language, a human-readable data-serialization language often used for configuration files.

BigQuery.definition: A fully-managed, serverless data warehouse that enables scalable analysis over petabytes of data, offered by Google Cloud.

DynamoDB.definition: A fully managed NoSQL database service provided by Amazon Web Services that offers fast and predictable performance with seamless scalability.

Elastic Search.definition: A distributed, RESTful search and analytics engine capable of solving a growing number of use cases, commonly used for log and event data analysis.

Grafana.definition: An open-source platform for monitoring and observability, used to query, visualize, alert on, and understand metrics from different data sources.

Helm.definition: A package manager for Kubernetes that helps you manage Kubernetes applications.

Kafka.definition: An open-source distributed event streaming platform used for building real-time data pipelines and streaming applications.

Kerberos.definition: A network authentication protocol designed to provide strong authentication for client/server applications by using secret-key cryptography.

MongoDB.definition: A source-available cross-platform document-oriented NoSQL database program, known for its flexibility and scalability.

OIDC.definition: OpenID Connect, an authentication protocol based on the OAuth 2.0 family of specifications, used for single sign-on (SSO).

PostgreSQL.definition: A powerful, open-source object-relational database system with a strong reputation for reliability, feature robustness, and performance.

Prometheus.definition: An open-source systems monitoring and alerting toolkit, designed for reliability and scalability.

RabbitMQ.definition: An open-source message-broker software that implements the Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP).

Rust.definition: A multi-paradigm, general-purpose programming language focused on performance and safety, especially safe concurrency.

Tibco EMS.definition: TIBCO Enterprise Message Service, a messaging middleware that simplifies and accelerates the integration and management of data distribution.

.NET.definition: A free, cross-platform, open-source developer platform for building many different types of applications, developed by Microsoft.

Airflow.definition: An open-source platform to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor workflows, developed by Apache.

Aurora RDS.definition: Amazon Aurora is a MySQL- and PostgreSQL-compatible relational database built for the cloud, part of Amazon RDS (Relational Database Service).

Chromium.definition: An open-source web browser project that forms the basis for the Chrome web browser.

Chronicle.definition: A cloud service from Google Cloud for security analytics and threat intelligence.

CSS.definition: Cascading Style Sheets, a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML or XML.

CUDA.definition: A parallel computing platform and application programming interface (API) model created by NVIDIA, allowing software to use certain types of graphics processing units (GPUs) for general purpose processing.

EC2.definition: Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) is a web service that provides secure, resizable compute capacity in the cloud.

FedRAMP.definition: The Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program, a U.S. government-wide program that provides a standardized approach to security assessment, authorization, and continuous monitoring for cloud products and services.

Fortran.definition: A general-purpose, compiled imperative programming language that is especially suited to numeric computation and scientific computing.

GCP.definition: Google Cloud Platform, a suite of cloud computing services offered by Google.

Golang.definition: Another name for Go, an open-source programming language that makes it easy to build simple, reliable, and efficient software.

Gradle.definition: An open-source build automation tool that is designed to be flexible enough to build almost any type of software.

HTML5.definition: The fifth and current major version of the HTML standard, used for structuring and presenting content on the World Wide Web.

Kotlin.definition: A modern, statically typed programming language that boosts productivity and developer happiness, officially supported for Android development.

OpenACC.definition: A user-driven directives-based performance-portable parallel programming model designed for scientists and engineers who want to easily accelerate their code for high-performance computing.

Pub/Sub.definition: Publish/Subscribe, a messaging pattern where senders (publishers) do not program messages to be sent directly to specific receivers (subscribers). Also refers to Google Cloud Pub/Sub, a messaging service for exchanging event data among applications and services.

SAML.definition: Security Assertion Markup Language, an open standard for exchanging authentication and authorization data between parties, in particular, between an identity provider and a service provider.

Spinnaker.definition: An open-source, multi-cloud continuous delivery platform for releasing software changes with high velocity and confidence.

VPC.definition: Virtual Private Cloud, a private network within a public cloud environment, such as AWS or GCP, that provides isolation and security for resources.

C.definition: A general-purpose, procedural computer programming language supporting structured programming, lexical variable scope, and recursion.

C#.definition: A modern, object-oriented programming language developed by Microsoft as part of its .NET initiative.

C++.definition: A general-purpose programming language created as an extension of the C programming language, supporting object-oriented, generic, and functional features.

Cassandra.definition: A highly scalable, distributed NoSQL database designed to handle large amounts of data across many commodity servers.

CircleCI.definition: A continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) platform for automating the build, test, and deployment process.

cuBLAS.definition: A GPU-accelerated library for dense linear algebra, providing BLAS (Basic Linear Algebra Subprograms) on NVIDIA GPUs.

cuDNN.definition: NVIDIA CUDA Deep Neural Network library, a GPU-accelerated library for deep neural networks.

CUTLASS.definition: CUDA Templates for Linear Algebra Subroutines and Solvers, a collection of CUDA C++ templates for high-performance matrix-multiplication at all levels and scales within CUDA.

ECS.definition: Amazon Elastic Container Service, a fully managed container orchestration service that supports Docker containers.

Elasticsearch.definition: A distributed, RESTful search and analytics engine capable of solving a growing number of use cases, commonly used for log and event data analysis.

GitHub.definition: A web-based platform used for version control and collaborative software development using Git.

HALIDE.definition: An open-source programming language designed to make it easier to write high-performance image and array processing code on modern machines.

HIP.definition: Heterogeneous-compute Interface for Portability, a C++ runtime API and kernel language that allows developers to create portable applications on AMD and NVIDIA GPUs.

IREE.definition: Intermediate Representation Execution Environment, an open-source compiler and runtime for machine learning workloads.

LLVM.definition: A collection of modular and reusable compiler and toolchain technologies, used to develop compiler front ends and back ends.

MLIR.definition: Multi-Level Intermediate Representation, a compiler infrastructure project intended to provide a common intermediate representation for high-level and low-level code transformations.

OpenCL.definition: Open Computing Language, a framework for writing programs that execute across heterogeneous platforms including CPUs, GPUs, and other processors.

OpenMP.definition: An application programming interface (API) that supports multi-platform shared memory multiprocessing programming in C, C++, and Fortran.

ROCm.definition: Radeon Open Compute, an open-source platform for GPU computing on AMD devices.

SIMD.definition: Single Instruction, Multiple Data, a class of parallel computers in Flynn's taxonomy, used in processors to perform the same operation on multiple data points simultaneously.

Step.definition: A single operation or stage in a process, often used in the context of CI/CD pipelines or workflow automation.

TVM.definition: An open-source machine learning compiler stack for CPUs, GPUs, and specialized accelerators.

XLA.definition: Accelerated Linear Algebra, a domain-specific compiler for linear algebra that can accelerate TensorFlow models.
